function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The generated code currently stores users and chats in memory, which means that all data will be lost when the server is restarted. A better approach would be to use a database to persist this data. This could be a SQL database like PostgreSQL or MySQL, or a NoSQL database like MongoDB or Firebase. This would allow the data to persist across server restarts and also make it easier to handle multiple concurrent requests.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The current implementation of the login function does not handle the case where the user does not exist in the system. If a user tries to log in with an email that is not registered, the server will return a 401 Unauthorized error with the message "Invalid credentials". It would be more user-friendly to return a more specific error message in this case, such as "User does not exist". This would make it easier for the user to understand what went wrong and how to fix it.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The current implementation does not include any form of password security. The user's password is stored in plain text, which is a significant security risk. It would be better to store a hashed version of the password instead. This way, even if someone gains access to the database, they won't be able to see the actual passwords. Python's hashlib library can be used to easily hash passwords.
